G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u202f3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 185C, § 3**, which grants the Housing Court jurisdiction over all civil actions involving the health, safety, or welfare of occupants of residential housing, including claims arising under **G.L. c. 186, § 14**.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u202f14.proposition: Massachusetts law implies a **covenant of quiet enjoyment** in every residential tenancy, codified at **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, which prohibits landlords from “directly or indirectly interfering with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7\u202f8A.proposition: - **G.L. c. 239, § 8A** (providing defense and counterclaim remedies for breach of quiet enjoyment and habitability).

State Sanitary Code 105 CMR 410.000.proposition: Order Defendant to remediate all water intrusion and mold conditions, ensuring the apartment is brought into compliance with **State Sanitary Code 105 CMR 410.000** and **G.L. c. 111, § 127L**;

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u202f127L.proposition: Order Defendant to remediate all water intrusion and mold conditions, ensuring the apartment is brought into compliance with **State Sanitary Code 105 CMR 410.000** and **G.L. c. 111, § 127L**;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case concerns constructive eviction and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment caused by severe noise from a bar the landlord introduced and could control. It does not involve water intrusion, physical defective conditions of the premises, or general failure to maintain habitability; rather, it addresses noise as an interference. While the opinion mentions habitability in passing, it does not stand for a consistent Massachusetts rule about water intrusion or defective conditions specifically, so citing it for that broader proposition is inaccurate.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly treats repeated flooding and unsanitary water intrusion as both (1) a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and (2) an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, grounded in the landlord’s duty to maintain watertight, sanitary premises. The court affirms liability and attorneys’ fees under § 14 based on Gem’s failure to prevent repeated flooding, explicitly tying that failure to maintain habitable conditions to interference with quiet enjoyment. Although the quiet-enjoyment damages award is vacated as duplicative, the court’s legal analysis clearly recognizes unremedied flooding/unsanitary conditions as a violation of the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.… [Gem] violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Davis v. Comerford, 483 Mass. 164 (2019).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case is directly about the scope of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and discusses when defective or unmaintained premises violate that covenant. While the holding is that a mere statutory lead paint violation is not automatically a § 14 violation, the Court expressly reaffirms prior cases holding that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which it has notice (such as leaky roofs, flooding, or failure to make premises habitable and keep them so) constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it supports the broader proposition that unremedied defective or uninhabitable conditions can violate quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment–type issues only in the context of rent abatement for code violations and does not frame them as violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court lists various sanitary code violations and upholds a damages award for breach of the warranty of habitability, but it neither analyzes nor holds that these conditions constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition that such conditions are violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: "Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs. … Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability…"

Alfano v. Donnelly, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 31.raw_text: Alfano v. Donnelly, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 310 (1995)
Alfano v. Donnelly, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 31.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Alfano v. Donnelly, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 31.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns trust law, the funding and termination of a Massachusetts business trust, and related fiduciary issues. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, habitability, water intrusion, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that unremedied water intrusion or defective conditions violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Alfano v. Donnelly, 38 Mass. App. Ct. 31.relevant_excerpt: “We consider, next, the plaintiff’s prayer for relief that the Realty Trust be terminated and its assets transferred to the plaintiff as sole beneficiary. The question is whether the holder of all the outstanding shares of a Massachusetts business trust may terminate the trust prior to its scheduled date of termination without the power to do so being reserved in the trust instrument and against the objection of the sole trustee.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case deals with loss of heat and hot water as a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the resulting right to rent abatement; it does not analyze or decide claims under the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion repeatedly frames the issue in terms of the warranty of habitability, contract principles, and statutory rent-withholding, not quiet enjoyment. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that unremedied water intrusion or defective conditions constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even though the facts involve habitability defects.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

Wesson v. Leone Enters., 437 Mass. 708 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that unremedied water intrusion, defective conditions, or failure to maintain habitable premises constitute violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
Wesson v. Leone Enters., 437 Mass. 708 (.support_reasoning: The case involves roof leaks and water intrusion, but it is a commercial lease decision about abandoning the independent covenants rule and adopting mutually dependent covenants, not about the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts habitability/quiet enjoyment jurisprudence. The court explicitly finds no constructive eviction and analyzes the landlord’s breach as a failure of an essential promised benefit under Restatement § 7.1, not as a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It therefore does not stand for the proposition that unremedied water intrusion or failure to maintain habitable premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and in fact applies a different doctrinal framework.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., 437 Mass. 708 (.relevant_excerpt: “We next consider whether the landlord’s actions regarding the leaky roof constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment amounting to the constructive eviction of the tenant. … While the landlord’s breach of his covenant to repair may have made the tenant’s operation less convenient and more expensive, based on the evidence adduced at trial, it did not rise to the level of a constructive eviction.”
